description: From Middle English gadling (“companion in arms; man, fellow; a person of low birth; rascal, scoundrel; bastard; base, lowborn”), gadeling (“vagabond”), from Old English geaduling, gædeling (“kinsman, fellow, companion in arms, comrade”), from Proto-West Germanic *gaduling, from Proto-Germanic *gadulingaz, *gadilingaz (“relative, kinsman”), equivalent to gad +‎ -ling. Related to Old English gāda (“comrade, companion”).

entries.meaning: (obsolete) A companion in arms, fellow, comrade.
examples: Gedlyngis, I am a fulle grete wat.

entries.meaning: A roving vagabond; one who roams
A man of humble condition; a fellow; a low fellow; lowborn; originally comrade or companion, in a good sense, but later used in reproach
A spike on a gauntlet; a gad.
